segments.text: 27 October, 1982, an interview with Dr. Jerry L. Green of the Los Alamos National Laboratory.
Dr. Green's a group leader of the MST-11 group and director of the lab's plutonium facility.
An interview for the Texas A&M Oral History Collection by Justin Green.
Dr. Green, could you briefly detail how you became involved with the Los Alamos National Laboratory and some of the steps of the career progression that have brought you to your present position?
Well, I was an undergraduate at the University of New Mexico.
I graduated in 1957.
However, I first went to Los Alamos in 1956 as a summer student.
at the end of my junior year.

I spent the summer of 56 at the laboratory in what at that time was referred to as CMB 11, a slightly different nomenclature, but was effectively the same group, same function that I'm associated with now.
At the end of the summer, I went back, finished my senior year at UNM, and graduated from the university in 1957.
And at that time I went back to Los Alamos and became a permanent member of the staff at Los Alamos, again working in CMB 11.
And I've effectively been associated with that group and the laboratory for my entire professional life, except for a minor stint when I left the laboratory to go to graduate school.
During the period between 1957 and 1961, when I left the laboratory to go back to graduate school, I went to night school in Los Alamos,
got a master degree in nuclear engineering.
Incidentally, my BS, the original degree I was working on, was in chemical engineering.
The master degree I got in night school at Los Alamos was, I believe it was properly referred to as a master degree in mechanical engineering with a nuclear engineering option.
The university at that time didn't have a nuclear engineering department.
And so the nuclear engineering degrees were handled through the mechanical engineering department.
In 1960, I believe, I finished the master's degree.
And in 1961, I decided to leave the laboratory for the period of time that would be required to finish my doctorate.
So I left the laboratory and went to the University of California at Berkeley.
where I was a student, a graduate student in the Department of Chemistry at Berkeley.
worked there until 1965 when I returned to Los Alamos.
The actual PhD degree was given, I believe, early in 1966, but I returned to Los Alamos about Christmas of 1965 and went back to work until the degree was actually bestowed.
I came back to the University, or to Los Alamos in 1965.

As I said earlier, I went back to the same group that I was in originally, and I've been there ever since, obviously as a staff member, and in the years since, I have become, gone up the ladder administratively.
I've been in a
an associate group leader, and then about five years ago was made the group leader of the group and have been that ever since.
Dr. Green, could you briefly describe the National Laboratory System, how it's operated by the Department of Energy, and what's the association of the National Lab with the University of California?
Well, in general, in a national sense, the national laboratories were set up to effectively take care of technical developments that were
too expensive for it to be reasonable for the private sector to pay for and accept the risk for.
And the government many years ago decided that the only way to be able to pursue some of these high risk and very expensive projects was to put them in
laboratories that have been established as effectively centers of excellence for that kind of development.
There are a number of national laboratories in the United States now.
Los Alamos, obviously, Livermore, the Argonne National Laboratory, Oak Ridge National Laboratory, Brookhaven National Laboratory, and Sandia National Laboratory.
I believe that's all of them at the present time.
There are a number of other laboratories that are not regarded as national laboratories per se, but they are to be considered as national resources technologically.
relationship between Los Alamos and the University of California and the way it associates itself with the Department of Energy National Laboratory System.

The University of California has been involved with Los Alamos since the inception of the laboratory in 1943 and has agreed to continue its association with Los Alamos after the war and obviously up to the present time.
It's my understanding, and I'm not being a lawyer, I don't really know the legalistic details of the contracts,
But there is a contract between, well, starting with the AEC and then going to IRTA and now to the DOE, a contract between the University of California and the government.
And then there was an additional contract between the University of California and Los Alamos.
And both of those contracts together effectively tied the Los Alamos National Laboratory
to the needs and requirements of the National Atomic Energy System, DOE, at the present time.
The same kind of contractual arrangement also exists, for instance, between DOE and the University of California and the Livermore National Laboratory in California.
Could you give a brief overview of the Department of Energy's plutonium program and what are your views on that program?
Well, the DOE doesn't have a plutonium program per se.
Plutonium obviously is a major
item that's involved in the nuclear aspects of the DOE's programs.
It is a fissile material and is obviously of substantial utility with regards to the manufacture of atomic weapons and also, and very importantly I feel, is also a
a major item in the development of nuclear reactors.
Most of the plutonium reactors, per se, are associated with the so-called breeder reactors.
It is a fuel for breeder reactors, and the breeder reactor generates plutonium that can be plowed back into the system, if you will, and used for additional reactors, starting them up.
Obviously, the weapons aspects of the use of plutonium is where it first started back during the war.
And the use of plutonium, most modern nuclear weapons involve at least some components of the device that are made from plutonium metal.
And so it has a substantial importance in that regard.
Can you describe the operational function of the TA55 plutonium facility and its standing as a center for plutonium research?
Well, TA55, the T incidentally simply stands for technical area.
It's a local acronym, if you will, for various technical areas in Los Alamos.
TA-55 is the major plutonium facility at Los Alamos.
By that I don't necessarily mean that all plutonium work at Los Alamos is done at TA-55.
There's substantial amounts that are done in other areas at Los Alamos.
But if you're talking about operations that involve massive amounts of plutonium in general, they are carried out at TA-55.
It's a large facility that is essentially dedicated to work with plutonium.
It was initially commissioned in 1978 and has been operating ever since.
The facility itself
is the facility was originally set up as essentially a research and development center for plutonium.
However, in the years since it was commissioned, there has been a substantial amount of quasi-production work that has been required by the DOE
and TE55 has been utilized to a major extent in trying to provide what was needed.
So there's a substantial amount of non-research and development work that goes on at TE55.
Well, obviously one of the primary functions of the facility is carrying out the plutonium-related aspects of nuclear weapons design and testing, if you will.
KE-55 and Los Alamos in general is not involved in the
the national nuclear weapons stockpile.
That's not the type of work that we're normally involved with.
What we are associated with instead is effectively the development of prototype devices that can eventually be inserted into the weapons stockpile.
In addition to that, there are significant programs that have gone on in the last few years that are associated with, for instance, advanced fuels and liquid metal fast-breeder reactors.
We've been involved in the development of, for instance, the uranium-plutonium carbide as an LMFBR fuel since August.
the early 1960s and have been heavily involved with it ever since.
There are also projects that are associated with some special isotopes of plutonium.
Plutonium-238, for instance, is used for the manufacture of what are effectively radioisotopic heat sources.
They, in some cases, are used simply for that, as heat sources.

For instance, some of these heat sources are inserted in various deep space probes, and their function is to generate heat and keep various electronic components, for instance, warm enough to operate reliably.
In addition,
manufacture or develop heat sources that can be married to thermal electric generators.
And the plutonium-230 heat source, once associated with a thermal electric generator, becomes a very long-term and stable electrical power source.
power sources of that type have been put on, again, space probes.

And when they're going deep space probes, it gets so far from the sun that solar collectors and solar electric generators are no longer sufficiently effective than the thermal electrics can take over.
run for the number of years
probes life.
Some of these thermoelectric generators, for instance, are sitting on the moon right now.
These 230 gauge heat sources were sent to the moon and are still sending back or powering equipment that sends back various types of information.
The seismic equipment on the moon now is still sending back information and is being powered by
What are your feelings on the massive involvement the civilian industry has recently taken in the nuclear weapons industry?
Oh, I don't think that the trying to categorize it as a recent involvement is quite correct.
I think the private sector has been involved to a major extent throughout the
the years that nuclear weapons have been in existence.
I think that the nuclear weapons stockpile is a very large and complicated system, and it, I think,

well it has been set up in a way that involves the private sector it might be possible for all of that work to be done strictly in governmental laboratories but I think that probably would not be terribly effective or efficient as to whether or not one should imply from your question that there may or may not be a
It may or may not be proper for the private sector to be involved.
I really don't have any strong feelings on that.
The work has to be done, whether it's done by the private sector or the government, is really a pragmatic question as far as I'm concerned, who can do it and do it the best.
It works very well, and when you've got a good thing, don't fool with it, I guess.
Are the security measures currently in effect in regards to the National Laboratory and specifically in relation to weapons-grade plutonium or uranium?
Do you feel that those are currently a reasonable defense effort?
I think that it's perfectly reasonable.
However, I think it should be pointed out that
Essentially, no safeguard system can be absolutely foolproof.
You can't have a safeguard system that allows you the freedom to get the work done that completely eliminates all possibility, for instance, of diversion.
That possibility is always going to exist.
The only way, for instance, that I can say that a given facility is completely free from any possibility of diversion is to slam the front doors and send everybody home.
You have to have people involved in doing the work.

fortunately or unfortunately the weak link in any kind of security system is the people and whether or not you can take a particular group of people and say these people are absolutely trustworthy unfortunately that's very rarely possible we do involve ourselves in some
fairly rigorous techniques for trying to filter up people that might be a problem.
But again, that kind of procedure is simply not foolproof, and I see no good way to make it so.

To your knowledge, have there ever been any specific instances or operations in which security has been compromised or in which an appreciable quantity of a weapons-grade material has been lost or taken?
Your question really had two parts.
I think with regards to the first part, I really am not particularly knowledgeable with regards to security breaches, that is, informational leaks.
The question of whether or not there have been significant amounts of material diverted, I think is what you were referring to in the second part of the question.
To my knowledge, there has never been any well-documented or situation where it could be positively stated that material had, in fact, been diverted.
It is frankly my opinion that generally significant amounts of material probably have not been diverted.
Now, I can't see that positively from first-hand knowledge.
but I know of no major diversions, certainly not from Los Alamos.
Now that does not necessarily mean that material has not been lost at one time or another.
There have been situations where material has either by accident or from just plain ineptitude been lost from the system.
But I really don't know of any situation where I can say of my own knowledge that material has

Do you believe that if a sizable enough quantity of material were diverted and, for example, were sold to some group, that it would be possible with the common knowledge or the technology commonly available to the average man to construct some sort of device that could be used more or less as a weapon?
Oh, I think there's absolutely no doubt that if sufficient amounts of material were made available, possibly not to the common man, as you put it, but there are many, many people that are
available that have the technical background to take a sufficient amount of material and make a rudimentary device.
I think that the chances are that it would be very inefficient, but in general
the kinds of things that clandestine diverters would be interested in manufacturing, I think high efficiency and high yield are really not a major concern.
I think in a lot of cases, devices that might be built to use in nuclear blackmail situations
whether or not they really work or not is not a major concern in the blackmail scenario.
I think that all they have to do is make a good-sized mess, and they've served their function.
But I, yes, I think that given a sufficient amount of material, it would not be incredible at all
for rudimentary devices to be manufactured by non-experts, if you will.
What are some of your perspectives and how might they have changed since you were a student at Berkeley on the anti-nuclear crusade?
That covers a multitude of sins.
The anti-nuclear...
Well, I don't think I'd really like to refer to it as a crusade, although in some cases that's the way it's handled.
There are people that do have legitimate personal concerns, and I would not for a minute try to suggest that people of that sort should not express those concerns.

I think that in many cases, much of the noise that's been generated by the so-called anti-nuclear movements are, as I say, in most cases, I think, they are legitimate and they are genuinely concerned, and well, they should be.
There are certainly situations where
the nuclear devices that modern man has to deal with can be dangerous.
There's absolutely no question about that.
I think that generally though that much of the noise and flap that is raised by the so-called anti-nuclear movement
principally based on ignorance.
And that's unfortunate.
And frankly, I think that a substantial amount of the blame for that kind of a situation may very well have to be placed at the feet of the so-called experts.
And I guess I'll have to place myself in that category, too.
People are dealing with the situation out of fear.
And I think it's fear born in ignorance.
And unfortunately the fact that they're ignorant has to be to a certain extent blamed on the people that are not ignorant.
In the past few years, I think people that are associated with the nuclear industry have been trying to provide information to the public.
But it's frustrating.
It's frustrating to me because information that we do put out either is not understood intentionally or unintentionally.
I can't really comment as to
to what the problem is there, but oftentimes when we in good faith go out and try to provide information, it gets turned around like a snake in a hole and it bites us.
It's very difficult to handle in what I regard as a reasonably responsible way.
The public deserves the information, absolutely.

Unfortunately, the information is sufficiently complex that it is a very difficult problem trying to decide or to come up with a technique to provide the information to the man on the street, if you will, in a format that he can understand.
When you were a student at Berkeley, did you have any problems or were there any roots of the anti-nuclear crusade within the free speech movement that was active at that time on campus?
As I recall, when I was at Berkeley, the free speech movement was in progress.
However, as I recall, they had no particular involvement with the anti-nuclear issue.
When I was there as a student, it was a little bit difficult to determine just exactly what the free speech movement stood for.
The young gentleman that was the leader of that movement and got it started was a fellow by the name of Mario Savio.
and he was there at the same time that I was at Berkeley.
Frankly, just exactly what Mr. Savio stood for, I have a little bit of difficulty trying to

determine at this point frankly at the time as a student I viewed it somewhat simplistically probably but Mr. Savio and his cohorts were just a bunch of ding-a-lings as far as I was concerned they really were I'm sure they thought they had something to say but I'm darned if I know what it was
It was an interesting situation.
I learned some things about the way that these so-called movements operate, and it was interesting to me.
I was a student on the campus at the same time they were holding their demonstrations, and it gave me a

at least relative to that particular situation something of an insight as to the way that people information and the media were manipulated by those groups I will have to say that they did it very well but I can remember any number of
demonstrations, if you will, that took place on campus that I personally viewed there'd be

15, 20, 30 people clustered together having a demonstration and the media would be there with their cameras doing what they're supposed to be doing and I'd go home at night and see those see the films played back on that particular demonstration and my goodness it looked like there were hundreds of people involved and they had the whole campus disrupted
It was absolutely untrue.
That was not the situation at all.
And it was interesting to me how, and I very frankly feel that, well, certainly in that particular case,
